title: 107_hr1287
content: The Act titled "Vaccine Injured Children's Compensation Act of 2001" amends the Public Health Service Act to establish a remedial program for vaccine-injured children. This program is to be interpreted liberally in terms of causation and damages, with no application of sovereign immunity. Section 2113 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to change the standard of evidence required for vaccine injury claims. When there is an equal balance of positive and negative evidence, a belief that the petitioner's claims are well grounded is sufficient. The standard of evidence for vaccine injury claims is changed under Section 2113 of the Public Health Service Act. The benefit of the doubt is given to the petitioner in resolving issues, and any defense by the respondent must be proven with clear and convincing evidence. The standard of evidence for vaccine injury claims is changed to give the benefit of the doubt to the petitioner. The evaluation of damages and future needs should consider the entire record and the course of injury. SEC. 4. COMPENSATION ISSUES. Section 2115 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include provisions for the establishment and maintenance of a trust to receive program funds, with no reduction to net present value applied to this portion of a petitioner's award. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include provisions for a trust to receive program funds without reducing a petitioner's award. Additionally, expenses for family counseling and training related to vaccine injuries may be reimbursed. The special master or court may award payments for attorneys' fees and costs incurred by the petitioner with respect to the petition, not more frequently than once every 90 days. SEC. 5. LIMITATIONS OF ACTIONS. Section 2116 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to extend the time period for filing a petition by an additional 36 months from the date the petitioner first knew or reasonably should have known about their eligibility. The statute of limitations for filing a petition under section 2111 of the Public Health Service Act shall be extended by 72 months. Additionally, the statute of limitations will be tolled until the petitioner reaches the age of 18, or 24 months after a guardian is appointed if the petitioner is incompetent. The statute of limitations for filing a petition under section 2111 of the Public Health Service Act shall be extended by 72 months. If denied compensation due to failure to meet requirements or deadlines, the petitioner can refile within 72 months after reaching the age of majority or within 24 months after the effective date of the Amendments.
